p:
Given that these patterns of inter-specific differences in physiological traits for both thermal and moisture reaction norms reflect differences in morphology ( Schmalfuss 1984, Broly et al. 2015), it can be predicted that there would also be a parallel pattern in thermal and moisture reaction norms for behavioural and life history traits. Aggregation in isopods is a behavioural tactic that reduces respiratory rates and water loss ( Allee 1926), further elaborated by Friedlander (1965), Cloudsey-Thompson and Constaninou (1987), Caubet et al. (2008), and Broly et al. (2014). This morphologically related hypothesis is supported by both the peak of the thermal response curve and the gradient of the thermal reaction norm for aggregation being higher for
O. asellus
than for either
P. scaber
or
A. vulgare
.
